A review of melting and freezing processes of PCM/nano-PCM and their application in energy storage
Sara Rostami a, b, Masoud Afrand c, d, *, Amin Shahsavar e, M. Sheikholeslami f, g, Rasool Kalbasi h, Saeed Aghakhani h, Mostafa Safdari Shadloo i, Hakan F. Oztop j

https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2020.118698 0360-5442/© 2020 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Phase change materials (PCMs) are capable of storing energy as latent energy by changing the phase and provide the stored energy when they are returned to their initial phase at a desired time. Due to the varying melting temperature of these materials, their application in air conditions of buildings, as well as the provision of hygienic hot water has received much attention, recently. This paper first provides a detailed illustration of phase change materials and their working principle, different types, and properties. Then a characteristic example of PCMs in solar energy storage and the design of PCMs are reviewed and analyzed. Next, this paper focuses on the heat transfer, melting and freezing processes of PCM/nano-PCMS including different models and experimental research on the natural convection and thermal energy storage. Finally, some challenges and suggestions are presented following the conclusion of this article. It is found that these materials generally improve system efficiency. Without using mechanical equipment, these materials are naturally adapted to the temperature fluctuations of the environment, leading to a reduction in energy consumption and subsequently energy management.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, the importance of energy is so much that it is interpreted as an energy crisis. The energy crisis means the gradual shutdown of factories and power plants, disruptions in transportation, reduction of gasoline for vehicles, the closure of schools in the winter, no airplanes flying, etc. In the last hundred years, energy dependency has increased dramatically, and we are heavily dependent on fossil fuels that are running out. Coal, gas, and oil constitute about 80% of the world’s energy consumption. Energy consumption in the last fifty years has been higher than energy
ng 550000, Vietnam. Rostami), masoudafrand@
consumption in the two centuries before [1,2]. The US Energy Information Agency forecasts world energy consumption to grow by 57% by 2030. Due to the problems of fossil fuels (environmental pollution, limited and endless resources, renewability and direct policy influence), the world has shown a tendency for renewable energies including solar, wind (for wind machines), biomass [3], geothermal, hydrogen [4e6], nuclear energy [7], etc. Solar power comes from nature, and because humans do not interfere with its production, it does not cause pollution [8,9].
Simple technology, reducing air pollution and the environment, and most importantly saving fossil fuels for the future by converting them to essential living materials using petrochemical techniques, are the reasons for the need for solar energy [10e14]. The sun not only is a great source of energy, but it is also the beginning of life and the source of all other energies. According to
scientific estimations, it has born from about 6000 million years ago, producing 4.2 million tons of energy per second as a result of nuclear fusion [15]. Due to the sun’s weight, which is about 333 000 times the Earth’s weight, it could be a huge source of energy for the next 5 billion years. The diameter of the sun is 1.39 109 m, the temperature in the center of the sun is about 10e14 million C. The radiation is emitted from its surface at a temperature of about 5600 C by electromagnetic waves into space [16e18]. By measuring the solar radiation flux above the Earth’s atmosphere, we can calculate the total power received from the sun, which is about 1.8 1011 MW [19,20]. Of course, almost half of the total solar energy is absorbed by the atmosphere and just less than half of it is absorbed by the earth’s surface [21e23]. The energy thus obtained in the form of visible, infrared, and ultraviolet light is about 1 kWh/ m2 [24]. Fig. 1 shows the amount of primary energy produced from various sources in the US in 2009. It can be seen that the share of new energies is not significant [25,26].
The most important issue in solar energy is its absorption and storage. Solar energy is absorbed by different collectors for different purposes such as electricity generation, water heating, space heating, etc. [29]. The abundance and cheapness of energy at certain times of the day are important reasons for energy storage. Solar energy is abundant in the daytime, but one of the major drawbacks of this energy is its inaccessibility at night. Energy storage can also be used in the absence of the sun [30,31]. In some countries, such as China, where electricity is mostly used for home heating, due to the low cost of electricity per day and its high costs at night (due to peak hours of consumption), energy storage is an important solution [32,33].
Energy storage is done in mechanical, electrical and thermal
Fig. 1. Primary production of energies from v
forms. Thermal energy storage (TES) is carried out in sensible (through specific heat of materials such as water, earth, etc.) and latent (through phase change of materials such as paraffin, hydrated salt, etc.) [34,35]. PCMs are widely used in various industries including textiles, satellites, telecommunications and medicine due to the change in their states. Materials with the melting temperature of less than 15 C are used for air conditioning and extreme cooling in phenomena that do not undergo regular temperature changes, while those with the melting temperature higher than 90 C are used to prevent fires where temperatures may suddenly rise [36e38]. Fig. 2 shows melting enthalpy and its temperature for some PCMs.
PCMs are used in residential buildings (with 40% energy consumption) and industrial silos and factories (with 55% energy consumption). Their importance will be doubled when we look at the role of recycling and optimization of energy consumption in energy management [41,42]. For example, the use of these materials in the eastern and western walls leas to the energy-saving about 29% and the northern and southern walls of a residential home result in energy-saving about 19% [43]. In Fig. 3, heat transfer is plotted for buildings.
The main purposes of using PCMs in buildings are: using the sun’s natural heat for cooling and heating and using the heat stored by the heating and cooling systems. There are three general ways to use PCMs to research these goals: using PCMs on the building wall, using PCMs on ceilings and floors, using them in cold and hot storage tanks, reduce indoor temperature fluctuations, using PCMs in solar systems, and their application in textiles.
The use of PCM in the building (Fig. 4) can include PCM shutters, PCM layer in facing walls, floor heating systems and PCM roof
arious sources in the US in 2009 [27,28].
boards. By placing the PCM on the suspended ceiling, they are used as part of air conditioning systems. The use of PCM inwalls not only makes them lighter but also saves energy by reducing thermal loads [46,47]. These materials are usually made from hydrocarbons or hydrated salts that are used in combination with ferrous additives to increase the thermal conductivity [48,49].
Radiation heat transfer from the floor is better than convection heat transfer because of providing more appropriate heating and less space occupancy. By utilizing PCM in the floor materials and by assuming electrical heating, the electrical energy consumption can be reduced. In this way, at night when power consumption is less, the PCM material is melted and stores the heat as the electrical system is turned on. The heat is returned to the environment during the day leads to savings in power consumption and the creation of balance in power generation of power plants [50].
The increasing demand for energy consumption and the limitation of fossil fuels as running out of resources and increasing environmental pollutants make the issue of energy storage is of paramount importance. About 40% of all energy is consumed in the buildings such that 14% of which is consumed in space heating and cooling. The first reports of the use of these materials in the building emerged from the 1940s. Then, the use of these materials in buildings has been extensively studied since the 1980s, and today their use in the building industry has been increased considerably [51]. The use of PCMs is an effective energy-saving approach sorted as renewable energy sources. During the melting
process, the PCMs behave like a thermal battery with the capacity of latent heat and store the heat energy and release it during freezing. Considering the breadth and importance of PCMs in renewable and sustainable energy, this paper first provides a detailed illustration of phase change materials and their working principle, different types, and properties. Then a characteristic example of PCMs in solar energy storage and the design of PCMs are reviewed and analyzed. Next, this paper focuses on the heat transfer, melting and freezing processes of PCM/nano-PCMS including different models and experimental research on the natural convection and thermal energy storage. Finally, some challenges and suggestions are presented following the conclusion of this article.

sections.heading: 2. Aim of the present study
sections.text:
The most prominent feature of PCMs is the potential for thermal energy storage, as these materials, like a heat sink absorbs lot of energy at a constant temperature. Thermal conductivity is a property attributed to thermal energy transfer capability, and its low content will reduce the storage potential. Therefore, researchers have always sought to apply techniques to improve heat transfer rates inside PCMs. Installing fins, loading metal foams and using pin-fins are some of the techniques that have received a lot of thoughtfulness. On the other hand, today’s technology has led to more nanoparticles (these materials have very high thermal
conductivity) being produced at a lower cost. Adding nanoparticles can improve the heat transfer rate within the PCMs. Because these materials have very low thermal resistance and can be used as a path with low thermal resistance to transfer thermal energy. However, these substances also affect the viscosity and exacerbate the viscous force. On the other hand, convection in the liquid PCM depends on the buoyancy as well as viscous forces. Adding nanoparticles intensifies buoyancy force while also exacerbating viscous force. Therefore, adding nanoparticles has a positive effect and a negative effect. In this paper, the competition between positive/ negative effects is analyzed in different applications. In other studies [52], researchers have focused more on changes in thermophysical properties caused by the presence of nanoparticles. But in this study, the main focus is on the analysis of the melting and freezing phenomena in the presence of nanoparticles. Moreover, more comprehensive study is conducted to assess the nano-PCM applications.

sections.heading: 3. PCMs and their different types
sections.text:
PCMs are organic or inorganic compounds that absorb large amounts of heat energy. Thermal energy storage in these materials occurs during the phase change process. These materials absorb and give back the thermal energy to the environment when the solid to liquid and liquid to solid phase change occurs, respectively. The PCMs have the potential to retain latent heat energy without any change even after thousands of phase change cycles [53]. When they are used indoors, they exchange large amounts of heat with the environment through consecutive cycles of melting and freezing due to extreme changes in air temperature (e.g. between night and day), providing a more balanced air temperature for indoors [54].
Another application of PCMs is in food transport equipment and machinery. Food transportation is one of the most difficult tasks in the freight industry. Foods often cannot last long under normal conditions due to the possibility of spoilage and deformation. Besides, transportation of some foods to distant places is somewhat impossible. On the other hand, the difference between night and creating of a constant temperature in the cabin of PCMs in different days and various environments are difficult. Today, a variety of trucks equipped with refrigerators and freezers is produced based on the advancement in the science and achievement of various mechanical and thermodynamic knowledge, including the use of PCMs [55,56]. For example, Fig. 5 shows that a system can adjust the temperature of food throughout the journey.
Numerous studies were conducted to reveal the successive usage of PCMs in buildings and the reduction of energy consumption for heating and cooling as well as providing comfort conditions to the residents [59,60]. According to the results of the application of these materials in the building, the fluctuations of indoor air temperature are significantly reduced and it is easy to maintain the proper ambient temperature at optimum body temperature [61]. PCMs are special cases of the solid-liquid state which are solutions used to control heat and received the attention of many researchers in the last decades because of the latent heat for solid-to-solid or liquid-to-liquid cases are less than that for solid-to-liquid (melting) case. As shown in Fig. 6, these materials are categorized in three classes of organic, inorganic, and eutectic [62,63].
Once a solid is heated, it absorbs energy to reach its melting point and then changes from solid to liquid. PCMs have the property of changing their phase at a given temperature range, in the sense that they maintain their temperature during the phase change [65]. In fact, they are heated in parallel with the environment during the heating process until they reach their melting temperature (phase change). After reaching this temperature,
although the ambient temperature continues to increase, the temperature of the materials and their surrounding environment remain constant and resist temperature rise due to the changing phase [66]. During this period, which usually lasts several hours, PCMs absorb large amounts of ambient heat but do not spend it for increasing their temperature [67,68]. During the phase change process (Fig. 7), they maintain their and surrounding temperature (see Fig. 8).
Most common PCMs in industries have low thermal conductivity, leading to a reduction in the efficiency of some systems that use these materials for energy storage. As a result, such systems face inappropriate economic justification. Various techniques are used for the improvement of such energy storage systems. These techniques are: using extended surfaces (fins) [71,72], using a network of PCMs with several materials [72e74], microcapsules PCMs [75e77], and increasing thermal conductivity of PCMs [78]. Because of their higher thermal conductivity and lower density, fiber filters and carbon nanomaterials are the two most common components used to improve their thermal conductivity [79,80]. Carbon materials have high resistance against chemical reactions and corrosion, making them compatible in every situation. By and large, fibers or carbon fibers can be added to the PCMs by melting and shear mixing techniques [81].

sections.heading: 4. Types of PCMs
sections.text: PCMs are classified into three categories: organic, inorganic and eutectic. In Fig. 6, the temperature ranges of the PCMs and their thermal conductivity are given.

sections.heading: 4.1. Organic PCMs
sections.text:
Organic materials are divided into two groups of paraffin and non-Paraffins. Organic materials with homogeneous melting, coreforming, as well as materials used as coatings are not corrosive. The organic PCMs used for heating and cooling of buildings have a melting point of 20e32 C.
Organic PCMs include paraffin and non-paraffins. Paraffin is a compound of straight chains. Due to availability of Paraffin in a wide range of melting temperatures, it is one of the best choices as a PCM for energy storage. Due to economic considerations, only industrial-purity paraffin can be used as PCM in latent thermal storage systems. Paraffin is safe, reliable, predictable, non-corrosive and cheap. Paraffin is chemically neutral and stable at temperatures below 500 C. In addition to the above properties, homogeneous melting and core-forming are two important characteristics of paraffin. Paraffin has drawbacks such as low conductivity, flammability, and incompatibility with the plastic case, although these drawbacks can be corrected with some changes in paraffinwax and storage unit [83e89].
Non-paraffins contain a large number of matters with variable properties. Some researchers have done extensive research on organic matter and eventually considered esters, fatty acids, alcohol, and glycol for energy storage. High latent heat, flammability, low conductivity, low ignition point, different toxicity and incompatibility at high temperatures are among the characteristics of non- Paraffins [90e94].

sections.heading: 4.2. Inorganic PCMs
sections.text:
Inorganic materials are classified into salt and metal hydrates. Inorganic compounds have a high latent heat per mass and volume, they are cost-effective, inexpensive and non-flammable in comparison with organic compounds. However, these materials have some issues like undercooling and separation (which affect the
properties of the phase change). The general principle of salt hydrates is as follows. The solidliquid phase change of salt hydrates is, in fact, the dehydration. Salt hydrates are a very important group of PCMs that have the following characteristics: High latent heat per volume, relatively high thermal conductivity, Low volume changes during melting, toxicity, homogenous melting, the density difference with water (which causes it to be deposited at the end of the case) and the formation of a weak core that causes under cooling [95e99].
Metal hydrates includes metals with a low melting point and eutectic metals. Due to the weight problem, these metals are not widely used. High latent heat per volume and high thermal conductivity are among the properties of these materials [100e102].
Eutectics are a minimum-melting of two or more components composition, each of which freeze and melts correspondingly creating a mixture of the component crystals through crystallization (Fig. 7). The coordinates that determine a eutectic point on the phase diagram are the ratio of the eutectic percentage (on the axis
of atomic/molecular ratio) and the eutectic temperature (on the axis of temperature) [103e105].
According to the explanations given above and the types of PCMs and based on Fig. 9 in which some PCMs and their thermal conductivity values are given, it can be observed that PCMs are divided into three categories in terms of application in different temperature ranges: low temperature, medium temperature and high temperature, which can be used in the construction industry, pharmaceutical, textile, electronics, solar collectors, and solar power plants, respectively.

sections.heading: 5. Properties of PCMs
sections.text:
According to the performance of PCMs, as shown in Fig. 10, energy storage systems must have the following attributions: i) suitable melting point at optimum temperature range, ii) enough surface of heat transfer, and iii) suitable enclosure compatible with of PCMs. The implementation of energy storage systems is often not economically feasible due to their more complex performance than conventional HVAC systems, as well as the need to use specialized and skilled personnel in the design and installation process [109e112]. Thus, the use of these systems in energy evaluation of buildings is considered when the following conditions are met in the building: the calculated maximum thermal loads are significantly greater than its averaged value. The building locates in a place with high-temperature differences during a day. This is
especially true in desert cities with hot days and cold nights. Using energy-saving systems in buildings is more cost-effective than purchasing energy-generating equipment such as boilers and chillers. The price of electricity consumed during the peak hours of the network is very different from other hours. The amount of electricity provided by the network is limited and the addition of the transformer requires a great deal of cost [113,114]. This is especially true in large industrial plants, commercial and residential buildings located in hot and humid regions that their electrical energy consumption is high enough to supply a cold load.
All human efforts in air conditioning are providing conditions wherein human comfort in the living environment. These efforts are accompanied not only by high costs and the consumption of fossil fuels but also results in environmental pollution and wiping out the energy sources. Energy consumption management in buildings is one of the ways to reduce energy consumption and environmental pollutants [65,115e117]. PCMs and energy storage systems are among the things that have become increasingly important in recent years in energy management in buildings. Storing the energy during unnecessary hours in walls and using them during peak hours is a promising approach. The sun, as an endless source, is of great importance in the field of renewable energies. The most suitable areas to use this energy are near the equator, where solar energy is the highest. Due to the great climate change in the world, the use of these systems can greatly save energy, reduce pollution caused by fossil fuels and decline heating
costs. On the other hand, as most desert regions have hightemperature differences during the day and night, this type of storage system can be used to absorb cooling energy in buildings and reduce electricity consumption [118e123]. In Fig. 11 a, b, applications of PCMs in a cooling system and a building wall, respectively.
The PCMs used in the heat storage scheme must have appropriate chemical, kinetic and thermophysical properties, as illustrated in Fig. 12.
Considering the investigations and properties of PCMs (Fig. 13), the use of organic PCMs is the most commonly used [83,84,88,123].
PCMs can be used in the three forms of raw material, micro, and macro. Since the application of these materials as rawmaterials can have disadvantages depending on PCM types and also due to their probability to flow in the liquid phase, the enclosures are required for keeping them in the liquid phase (Figs. 14 and 15). Therefore, they are usually used as packages of both micro and macro types in different industries [85e87,126].
To produce both micro and macro types, the PCMs are embedded in the enclosures and encapsulated. Hence, the major difference between the twomicrocapsules andmicrocapsules is the size of the enclosures or capsules used. In the microcapsule method, the material is embedded in tiny spheres with a diameter of 1e30 mm. In the microcapsule method (Figs. 16e18), materials are embedded in larger containers in envelopes or containers of different materials. Most of these containers are made of plastic bags as well as high-density polyethylene hard panels [128e133].

sections.heading: 6. Solar energy storage using PCMs
sections.text:
Along with the growing development of solar power plants, thermal systems such as receivers, collectors, and thermal energy storage have developed. Thermal systems are an important part of solar power plants. Fig. 19 shows the components used in a solar power plant and energy storage [136,137]. Thermal energy storage
is defined by the world energy agency as a device, something like a thermal battery, to store thermal energy in a tank for demand in another time for heating and cooling or power generation. Half of the accumulated energy is consumed as thermal energy. Since heat demand may vary throughout the day and from day to day, energy storage is used to balance energy demand during the day, week and even a season. Energy storage has a vital effect on reducing the peak of greenhouse gas emissions and has the potential to increase the efficiency of energy systems, either. Energy storages are especially useful for power and heat production in-home applications. Figs. 20 and 21 illustrate the use of thermal storage for home heating [138,139]. According to these applications, the storage must have the following properties [140,141] high ratio of volume to cost, high ratio of absorption to rejection capacity, durability and long life.
The results dealing with the application of using PCMs in thermal storages shows that energy consumption declines in some cases, even up to 22%, especially during peak hours of energy consumption. The benefits of using these materials in buildings can be related to the increased thermal comfort of residents following the reduction of temperature fluctuations. Also, another advantage of using this method is the reduction of severe temperature fluctuations in sensitive cases such as the temperature of greenhouses, solar heaters, and dryers which can affect the desired quality of the finished product [147,148].

sections.heading: 7. Design of thermal energy storage
sections.text:
It is easily understood that the liquid-solid phase change problems are more relevant than the liquid-gas and solid-gas phase changes because they have a higher thermal density. Figure (22) illustrates the preparation stages of the PCMs according to the work of Qian et al. [123].
However, several parameters must be considered by designers. In addition to technical features, as shown in Fig. 23, the productions must be affordable, environmental issues should be taken
into account, also thermal properties such as sensible and latent heat capacities have an essential impact on the size reduction and efficiency improvement. The heat transfer rate must be as much as possible to meet the thermal requirements during the absorption and rejection cycles [150e153]. On the other hand, the materials of the storage must be chemically and mechanically stable against successive thermal cycles. Also, the storage must be compatible with the operating fluid [154e156].
The constituent materials of the storage are different because the storage method is sensible, latent, and chemical. Sensible heat is the heat that causes temperature changes in the material. In thermal energy storage due to sensible heat, adding or removing energy from the energy storage material leads to an increase or decrease in its temperature. Thermal energy storage due to chemical reaction is another optimal method for storing thermal energy using the heat generated by chemical reactions. Thermal energy Storage due to latent heat includes the addition (or rejection) of thermal energy as latent heat to (or from) the body. As a result, the process of phase change occurs in the material. One of the features of this storage method is the ability to store energy in a volume much lower than the energy storage method due to sensible heat, which can be considered the most suitable method of energy storage if the space is limited and the system weight is maximum. PCMs used as latent storage in heating systems can absorb or release large amounts of heat during the phase change
process such as melting-freezing or distillation-evaporation [158e164].
Cryogenic energy storage systems are often divided into two categories: full and partial capacity storages. In the former case, the total required cold load is transferred to the non-peak time period during peak consumption. In other words, during non-peak hours inwhich the demand cost decreases, chillers operate at full capacity and store the cooling energy generated inside the system in the freezing process. During the day and during the time when electricity consumption is maximized and the cost of demand is high, the cooling generating system is switched off and the total cooling load required by the system is obtained by melting the phase change materials. It is mostly used when the peak period of consumption of the electricity distribution network is short or the cost of electricity consumption at peak times is high [165e169]. It should be noted that this system is also capable of providing cooling of the space when emergency power is cut off (Fig. 24).
In partial capacity storage systems, the chiller provides part of the maximum cold load required by the system and the rest is provided by the energy storage system. These types of systems can be implemented in both constant and variable load methods. In the first method, the chiller operates at full capacity for 24 h a day. In this case, if the load is greater than the capacity of the chiller, the overload will be provided by storage systems. When the required cooling load is low, the excess cooling generated by chiller is sent to
storage systems to be stored. In this type of system, the capacity of the chiller and the storage system is minimum (Fig. 25). In the second method, the energy storage system provides most of the required cooling load. The chiller operates with full capacity during non-peak hours and the cold produced is stored in the energy storage system. The partial capacity system is drawn in Fig. 26, schematically [141].

sections.heading: 8. Nanoparticles and heat transfer enhancement
sections.text:
Evaluation of the thermal properties of cooling liquids shows poor heat conductivity (except for liquid metals, which are not useable in most temperature ranges). For example, the thermal conductivity of water is about 30% of copper. It is clear that all works to enhance heat transfer by turbulence, surface enhancement, etc. are limited by natural limitations of thermal conductivity [172e174]. It is more than a century that the use of suspended solids mixtures has been proposed for the thermal conductivity enhancement. Maxwell [175] was the founder of establishing theories in predicting the thermal conductivity of suspendedmixtures. His attempts were followed up by many empirical studies and theories such as the works of Zhou [176], Xuan [177], Lee [178], and Das [179]. Further models presented in Refs. [180e183] were also
used in predictions. Nevertheless, all of these researches are restricted to particle suspensions in micro and millimeter dimensions, and such suspensions result in the following drawbacks [184e187]: The fast particles settle, making layers on surfaces, and decreasing the capacity of heat transfer. Sedimentation decreases as a response to a rise of chaotic fluid motion but corrosion of heat transfer devices, pipes, etc. rises speedily. The tendency for clogging increases along the channel flow path with the particle size. The pressure drop in the fluid augments substantially. Therefore, the path of particle formation in the fluid was well defined but not generally acceptable for heat transfer applications [188e192]. New material technology has developed the chance to create nano-sized particles that are completely different in optical, electrical, thermal and mechanical properties.
Choi et al. [193] introduced the idea of dispersing nano-sized particles into a liquid. To increase the heat transfer, the researchers added nanoparticles (particles smaller than 100 nm) to the fluid. This augmentation technique has previously been used with fluid-suspended microparticles to increase heat transfer in micro- and milli-channels. The surface-to-volume ratio of nanoparticles is 1000 times larger than micro-particles and can transfer heat greatly more efficiently. Choi et al. [193] showed that the addition of nano-additives to the common fluids could double the
heat transfer rate of those fluids due to the higher thermal conductivity of these particles. What makes the nanoparticles attractive as a potential candidate for making a mixture of particles with fluids is providing a large area for heat transfer, the momentum of the particles is low, and they have high mobility.
Haq et al. [194] investigated thermal management in singlewalled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs)/water nanofluid (Fig. 27). In this study, thermal conductivity was improved by heating
boundary conditions and the presence of SWCNT in the enclosure. Three different conditions (cold, hot and adiabatic) were used at the walls. This phenomenon is governed by nonlinear partial differential equations including continuity, momentum, and energy. The numerical solution method was the FEM to study the influences of cylinder conditions (hot, cold and adiabatic), heated zone length (A LH B), Rayleigh number (104 Ra 108), nanofluid concentration (0 ¼ ɸ 0.2), and the magnetization value (0 ¼ M 500) on the flow rate, and temperature distribution. The results showed that as the Ra and ɸ increase, this amount of heat transfer rate increases. Also, the thermal distribution increases as ɸ increases. In contrast, thermal distribution does not change with the magnetization.
When particles are dispersed properly, these nanofluid properties are predictable to have the following advantages.
i) Greater thermal conductivity: The nanoparticles higher surface area causes more heat transfer. 20% of nanoparticle atoms are on their surface for those smaller than 20 nm. This specificationmakes them accessible for heat exchange at any time. One more benefit is the mobility of the nanoparticles due to their small size, which can create micro-displacements and thus increase heat transfer [195e202].
ii) Stability: Since the particles are small, they have low weight, leading to a small tendency for settling. This reduction in sedimentation overcomes one of the major weaknesses of suspended mixtures (particle deposition) and makes nanofluids more stable [203e206].
iii) Micro-channel cooling without blockage: nanofluids are also
suitable for working in microchannel where they are exposed to great heat loads. The grouping of nanofluids and microchannels provides both high conductivity fluid and high heat transfer rate. Nanoparticles are much smaller than microchannels and do not cause clogging [207e209].
iv) Reduced corrosion probability: the size of the nanoparticles is very small and consequently their momentum effect on solid walls is very low, resulting in a reduction in the corrosion of pipelines, heat exchangers and pumps, to name a few [210,211].
The nanoparticles are classified into three categories of ceramics, puremetals, and carbon nanotubes, whichwill be discussed in more details. The various combinations of these nanoparticles and the base fluids including water, ethylene glycol, oils, and
toluene provide different nanofluids [212e214]. Although conventional PCMs are usually high in density, their low melting, and freezing rates reduce the potential of energy storage systems in specific applications. This is because almost all conventional PCMs have low thermal conductivity, although their values are increased by the use of high conductivity materials in various methods [215e219]. These methods are.
i) the saturation/distribution of high thermal conductivity porous materials/particles within PCMs,
ii) embedding metal compounds and structures in PCMs, and iii) using low-density high conductivity materials.
Although the use of graphite composite in PCMs improves their performance, some limitations have led researchers to look for other solutions. These limitations correspond to the production process of graphite composites which is time-consuming and costly. Therefore, some researchers have been looking for a solution to this problem in recent years. They found that by adding highconductive particles with micro- and nano-scale to the PCM, its thermodynamic properties are enhanced, leading to an increase in system efficiency. The embedded metal structure in the PCMs has been proposed as a technique to increase its thermal conductivity. In this technique, a metal sphere or a cylindrical tube (or other shapes) is used and placed in the PCM enclosure, which dramatically reduces the phase change time, as a consequence, its efficiency is increased (Fig. 28). High-density metal particles and compounds may sediment in the system and also increase the
weight of the system significantly. In addition, researchers showed that the compatibility with PCMs is not the intrinsic features for all metals. For instance, nickel is not compatible with paraffin, while aluminum particles are. These issues have led researchers to seek for high thermal conductivity, low-density materials which are broadly compatible [220e227].
Since carbon fiber density is lower than that of metals and its thermal conductivity is approximately equivalent to that of copper and aluminum, its use is promising to increase the efficiency of energy storage systems. In addition, carbon fiber has corrosion resistance and is therefore compatible with most PCMs. It is important to consider the uniform distribution of carbon fiber particles. Studies showed that systems in which carbon fiber particles are uniformly distributed in the PCM exhibit much more efficiency than that they are distributed randomly and non-
uniformly. Previous studies demonstrated that nanoparticles are most commonly used in paraffin PCMs [228e234].

sections.heading: 9. Nano PCMs
sections.text:
Themost important advantage of nanoparticles is improving the thermal properties provided by the large value of the surface-tovolume ratio. The reason for this is the increase of heat transfer surface and the collision of nanoparticles with their environment. Therefore, numerous researchers are examined the new properties of nanoparticles in different environments experimentally. One of these investigations is nanofluid preparation, which numerous researchers have examined the properties of nanofluids [235]. These properties are viscosity [236e238], thermal conductivity [239,240], density, specific heat, etc. [241]. Nanofluids have many applications in various industries, especially in the heat exchangers [184,242], solar industries [185], refrigeration [243], etc. Another application of nanoparticles is in the field of medicine and drug delivery [244,245]. Nano drug delivery is the subject of many medical researchers [246,247]. Nanoparticles are widely used in
many other fields in various industries, including aerospace, electronics, medicine, materials, metal coatings, etc. One of the most important applications is to add nanoparticles to the PCMs (Figs. 29e31).

sections.heading: 10. Melting and freezing of PCMs
sections.text: Since PCMs are mostly used as energy sources, lots of researches has been conducted to simulate the melting and freezing in different geometries including rectangular, circular, and spherical. Rectangular enclosures are widely used because of their simpler boundary conditions (Fig. 32).

sections.heading: 10.1. Melting and freezing models
sections.text:
During the melting process, the solid material chronologically changes its phase to semi-solid, mushy and then to liquid. During the freezing process, the reverse trend occurs. Therefore, six steps are required to complete the thermal process. At each particular stage, heat transfer occurs as convection and conduction [251]. In
this case, predicting the spatial motion of the melting front over time because it is nonlinear and moving; moreover, the heat transfer involves free convection and conduction. Because of these three factors, the governing equations at the interface are nonlinear. Thus, there is an exact solution to some problems. Alexiades [252] showed that there are many physical phenomena that occur during phase change, including the changes in the specific heat, volume, thermal conductivity, density, and over-cooling, which should be considered in the study of phase change using mathematical models. Due to the complexity of the subject, various methods have been proposed over the years to model and predict the melting and freezing phase change process. An overview of these methods is presented here.
Experimental methods are more accurate to exhibit the actual behavior of the phase change phenomena than numerical studies since the behavior of the phase change phenomena is examined directly by observation with no assumptions. However, in many areas such as large-scale and unsteady environments, experimental methods cannot be used. The properties of the experimental methods can be categorized as follows [252]: i) they consume a
great deal of time and expense, ii) the dimensions of the laboratory equipment should be appropriately selected according to the type of experiment. On the other hand, the space in which the equipment is located should also be selected according to these dimensions, iii) the equipment needed must be properly assembled, iv) appropriate environmental variables should be considered to simulate actual conditions, v) variation of variables must be accurately measured by calibrated devices. Further explanation of the analytical and numerical methods is presented.

sections.heading: 10.2. Stefan method
sections.text:
Stefan method is one of the first and simplest analytical methods to solve the melting and freezing phase change problems. In this case, heat transfer is considered only in the liquid phase and the solid phase remains constant at the melting temperature. The melting and freezing rates in a semi-infinite area can be evaluated by Stefan number, which is dimensionless and expressed as follows [254,255].
Ste¼ cðTh TmÞ hl
(1)
where hl and c denote the latent heat of the phase change and the specific heat of the liquid, respectively. Moreover, Th and Tm are the hot and the melting temperatures, respectively. Most of the solutions presented by Stefanmethod are one-dimensional with simple boundary and initial conditions.

sections.heading: 10.3. The neumann method
sections.text:
The development of the Stefan method for two-phase state is known as the Neumann method, which is much closer to the real state. In the Neumannmethod, the material is presumed to be solid with the initial temperature very different from the melting temperature, at first. Assuming constant the thermophysical properties, the Neumann problem is formulated as follows [256,257].
r cp vT vt ¼ k v 2T vx2

Simultaneously, the latent heat is absorbed by the PCM and the position of the liquid-solid boundary is determined using the energy conservation equation:

conditions in the Cartesian coordinate framework and assuming only conductive heat transfer [258].

sections.heading: 10.4. Fixed grid method
sections.text:
This technique is capable to use the standard solution process for energy equations and is suitable for multi-dimensional problems. In this method, the heat transfer equation is solved to
calculate the temperature by using FDM for derivatives. At each time step, as shown in Fig. 34, the moving boundary is set between two neighboring points of the grid, for example between mDx and (mþ1)Dx (at position fDx, 0 > f > 1.0).
The numerical solution of melting ice is a simple example of fixed grid method. The temperature at the upper point is obtained using the temperature of neighbors as follows:

The enthalpy and the effective heat capacity methods are two approaches based on the fixed grid method. Nevertheless, fixed grid method sometimes does not work optimally, especially when the interface at a time step leaps over more than one grids.

sections.heading: 10.5. The enthalpy method
sections.text:
In this method, enthalpy is considered as the temperature-
dependent factor. Using the enthalpy method, a two-phase region called mushy region is considered, which avoids the severe discontinuity due to numerical instability. This method was reported that is consistent with the practical problems because it
does not need to explicitly examine the phase change boundary [260].
The basic enthalpy approach can be explained as a conductioncontrolled transition in one-dimensional. The conservation energy is stated using enthalpy and total volume temperature in the phasechange procedure, through which a continuous function is obtained. Fig. 35 shows the temperatureeenthalpy diagram for the isothermal and non-isothermal phase change.
The energy conservation equation using temperature and enthalpy is as follows:
r vh vt ¼VðkVTÞ (12)
where h is the specific enthalpy expressed by the sensible and latent enthalpies:

The last right-hand side term of equation (16) shows the change in volume fraction versus the time. By placing the enthalpy value of relation (13) in equation (16), the melting line location is obtained so that wherever there is a volume fraction between zero and one, the melt line is located. The enthalpy method is also sometimes
referred to as the porous enthalpy method because it assumes that each grid is a solid and liquid porous medium. Due to the use of the enthalpy method in this research, more details are presented in the next sections.

sections.heading: 10.6. Effective heat capacity method (energy-based method)
sections.text:
The latent heat is obtained by the difference between the melting and freezing temperatures. A direct relation between the heat capacity and the energy augmentation/rejection of PCMs exists, while an inverse relationship exists with the temperature difference. This proportion is given by the following relation:
ceff ¼ hl
