where T1 and T2 are respectively the melting or freezing temperature and the temperature at which the material is completely frozen or melted.
This method in simulating phase change problems cannot accurately predict conditions when the temperature difference is low or the temperature is constant. Bonacina et al. [261] presented a one-dimensional model to increase the precision of the heat capacity method. Using heat capacity method, a multi-dimensional numerical solution was proposed by Rabin and Korin [262]. As can be seen from Fig. 36, there are considerable numerical simulations of phase change materials. By examining the above methods, it was concluded that the enthalpy method has been of much interest to researchers [263] (Fig. 37).

sections.heading: 11. Melting and freezing of PCMs and nano PCMs
sections.text:
The first studies on rectangular geometry were performed in 1975 and 1976 by Shamsundar and Sparrow [264e266] through the use of FDM. Hamdan and Elwerr [267] proposed a model for studying the melting process in a cavity. The melting rate was
largely dependent on thermal diffusion, adhesion, thermal conductivity, specific heat, and latent heat. Using the energy balance, Lacroix [268] provided a mathematical model to investigate the
contact melting of PCMs in a square cavity containing free convection. The results of this numerical study showed that the melt volume at the bottom of the cavity is greater than that of the case in which pure conduction is dominant. Free convection effect has been studied by Lamberg and Siren [269] to analytically discover how the melting front behaves in a semi-infinite PCM cavity with the presence of fins. This analytical model involves the solution of the Neumann equation, in a pure conduction problem. They also estimated the location of the melting zone using the exact solution of the Newman equation. A similar study was performed by
Lamberg et al. [270] in the presence and absence of free convection and a comparison was made against experiments. The results showed that ignoring the natural convection effect doubled the time of the maximum temperature. The spatio-temporal variation of the interface during the melting process in a rectangular cavity has been obtained by Stritih [271] experimentally and compared against analytical results. The results showed that analytical results accurate just in the acute response. But, the difference between the results increases considerably with the melting time. A cylinder
engulfed by hot water was studied by Regin et al. [272] to capture the melting front of paraffin capsules. The melting process was higher in the upper part of the cylinder than in the lower part of the cylinder. Also, free convection has a deep influence on the coincidence of the numerical and experimental results. The PCM-filled cylinder with heated-sidewall, shown in Fig. 38, was studied by Jones et al. [273]experimentally and numerically. Their results indicated that the melting layer along the vertical direction uniformly varies in the early stages. The thickness of the melting layer changes with time similar to the rectangular enclosure. This indicates the dominance of natural convection.
Melting of paraffin in a cylinder was studied by Akgün et al. [274]. They observed that the melted PCM expanded radially outward and forms a conical shape. Bahrami [275] performed experimental studies on PCMmelting in a sphere. The dome shape of the solid-liquid intermediate plate with higher at the top persists during melting process. Also, the solid PCM moves downward due to its higher density than liquid PCM and settled down to the bottom of the spherical cavity. Akhilesh et al. [276] numerically studiedmelting in a rectangular enclosurewith a heated upper wall (Fig. 39). This analysis involved examining the number of fins per unit length, leading to a rise in heat transfer and energy storage. They found that attaching more fins could not increase thermal efficiency significantly.
Gharebaghi and Sezai [277] investigated the efficiency of rectangular cavities with the presence of horizontal and vertical fins. In both cases, the heated wall was kept at a fixed temperature above the PCM melting temperature. The heat transfer rate is raised by attaching fins horizontally for the differentially heated sidewalls. Moreover, raising the distance between fins rises the heat transfer rate. It was also found that increasing the number of fins more than a certain amount results in a slight increase in the heat transfer. Declining the buoyancy effect, leading to the dominance of the conduction heat transfer mechanism. The phase change of a finattached enclosure shown in Fig. 40 has been studied by Lacroix and Benmadda [278]. This study investigated the effect of the number and length of fins on PCM melting rate. For short fins, the melting rate depended on the number of fins. They found that the melt front passing through the fins is almost similar to the case without fins. On the flip side, melting rate constantly increased with the fins number. The results also showed that at high
temperature difference, raising the fins number raises the heat transfer rate. They revealed that the optimal number of fins is also affected by the temperature of the hot wall. The research has been developed by Lamberg et al. [270] and Lamberg [279] to compare three configurations of no fin, single fin, and twin fin. These studies revealed that the heat transfer rate of the twin fin configuration is higher than a single fin, followed by the no fin system.
Fin thickness was studied by Shatikian et al. [280,281]. For the same sizes of rectangular cavities, the melting rate of the thicker case is slower than the thinner ones. Also, in thicker cavities, the fluid movement becomes more with the melting process time. On the other hand, in thin cavities, the fluid moves slowly in the
melting process. Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage (LHTES) was proposed by Deng et al. [282] with new positioning and shape of fins. These fins were tested in the lower half of the cavity and mirror positions relative to the centerline of the tube. An unsteady 2D numerical test was performed on the Luric acid melting process as PCM. The pair fins were used in the experimental test at the angles of 0 , 30 , 60 , 90 , 120 , 150 , and 180 . The results showed that at angles of 30 e120 are optimal to achieve complete melting time. Increasing the inclination angle, up to 120 , increases the heat transfer rate. In addition, it was found that by increasing the fin length, the LHTES role could be significantly improved rather than the base state. As the melting process continues, natural heat transfer dominates. This factor is such that a hole is created in the shell of the cavity. Two fins in the down hemisphere with an angle of 120 led to maximum natural heat transfer. It increases by increasing the fin length.
Blade embedding is an effective method to enhance heat transfer between PCM and heat transfer fluid (HTF). A proper arrangement of blades can play an important role in LHTES. Deng et al. [283] defined a two-dimensional model based on finite volume method (FVM) concerning natural heat transfer and found the effective order in the arrangement of the fins used in the design for charge rate in LHTES. They compared the results with experimental data (Fig. 41). First, the heat transfer characteristics of the LHTES unit were investigated by arranging different fins. These models include non-fin pair of tubes, pair of tubes with straight fins, pair of tubes with angular fins, pair of tubes with fins in lower hemisphere, and pair of tubes with fins in upper hemisphere. Then, the effect of the number of blades (N), dimensionless fin length (L), heat transfer fluid temperature (Tw) and outer tubematerials on themelting and fusion were studied for four models. Then, the best type of fin arrangement was proposed to increase thermal efficiency. Increasing the capability of the LHTES unit by applying the position
of the fins quantitatively based on the full melting time and heat storage capacity was described and the following results were obtained: The number of optimal fins is N 6. When angular fins are used N > 6. For N ¼ 6 only the length of the fins (L) can change the optimal value. In the case of angular fins, the optimal value of L is 0.5 and 0.95. At L ¼ 0.75, the optimal value is minimum. In the first 40 s of the melting process, it was observed that the melting process is due to the natural heat transfer. Finally, Deng et al. [283] studies the role of natural convective heat transfer in PCM melting by defining different models of the fins’ arrangement immersed in lauric acid. Based on the experimental data and simulation results, it is concluded that the area with the least volume fraction of melt can be moved and the melting time of PCM can be changed depending on the position of the fins in the enclosure. However, comparing the finned and unfinnedmodels, it is concluded that the charge rate in the unfinned model is higher than that of the finned ones due to the maximum melting time of PCM and thus trapping more heat energy due to natural convection heat transfer.
Poran and Ahmed [284]performed a two-dimensional model of PCM melting in the enclosure using ANSYS software. Seven different shapes of cavity and heat source were tested and a well agreement was reported against experiments. The results showed that heat source shape has a deep effect on the PCM melting process than the enclosure shape. It was then observed that the circular heat source improves the PCM melting process under adiabatic boundary condition. The melting efficiency of the circular source in the circular enclosure increases from 60% to 97%. So, if the heat source is covered by the PCM with the desired melting point may be useful in the process of heat rejection in electronic machines or other devices.
Bouhal et al. [285] investigated two-dimensional numerical analysis of solid gallium melts on porosity-enthalpy formulation to optimize the mold geometry (Fig. 42). The effects of geometry on PCM melting were investigated. Two designs were proposed, simple design and the one with 4 fins, which reduced the melting time from 18.35 to 13.35 min. In other words, the fins improve heat transfer and melting time.
Pourakabar and Darzi [286] studied the melting of PCMs in enclosures with different inner tube arrangements. Nine different cavities were examined. Their temperature was assumed to be constant and their walls were adiabatic. It was found that in early times, conduction heat transfer is the dominant mechanism. Then, the natural convection increases the melting process, especially the upper part is more affected. The lowest and the highest melting rates are associated with the dual tube and the single tube configurations. Also, the fastest and the slowest freezing times are allocated with the diamond arrangement and the dual-tube configuration. Injecting copper foam into the PCM acts as a catalyzer. It was reported that the temperature of the PCM varies slower than the metal foam. In addition, injecting metal foams almost doubled the melting and freezing rates.
Wang et al. [287] used a square cube cavity and studied various
metal foams combined with paraffin and other materials to make composite materials to determine effective heat transfer and thermophysical properties. A WeP model was used for the simulation of melting foam at a constant temperature using a combination of 6 types of tetradecahedron and two types of irregular dodecahedron. It was reported that the thermophysical properties of the metal foam and the PCM have a profound effect on the heat transfer of PCM composites when the porosity size has no considerable effect. The effective heat transfer of the PCM composite increases with the increase in heat transfer of the metal foam, which becomesmore andmore in its lower porosity. The effective thermal conductivity of PCM composites depends on the ratio of the metal conductivity to the conductivity of PCM. The melting front is highly affected by the metal foam microstructure and most of the heat transfer occurs in the liquid phase. While the porous structure is influenced by conduction rather than convection such that the thermal conductivity and the temperature are the most effective factors. The growth of the fluid phase varies non-linearly over time. The melting rate is very high in later stages but gradually decreases with time. In other words, the natural heat transfer is suppressed and conductive heat transfer is raised by increasing the percentage of porous materials in the composite.
Bondareva and Sheremet [288] simulated this process numerically. In this study, the two opposite walls had low heat transfer and the other walls were insulated with the bottom-attached heater. The governing equations were formulated non-dimensionally. The finite difference method was used. The distribution of velocity and temperature for different values of Ra and dimensionless time led to the understanding of flow patterns and heat transfer within the enclosure. It was observed that for the average values of the Rayleigh number, single thermal plume can be considered. For high values of Rayleigh number, double thermal plume is observed. The evolution of the phase-change process is a function of the mode of thermal plume and heating not only vertically but also horizontally. At high values of the Rayleigh number, rapid asymmetric development was observed. In the two-dimensional enclosure model, the process of melting was carried out rapidly, while the cooling of the material is a characteristic of the cubic cavities.
The natural heat transfer of paraffin melt in a cubic and rectangular cavity with a local heat source located on its bottom was studied by Bondareva and Sheremet [289] numerically. The governing equations were formulated in non-dimensional form. The potential-vortex equations and the flow-vortex equation have been solved through the use of the FDM for three- and two-dimensional simulations, respectively. Comparison between two- and threedimensional cases showed that the occurrence of melting is difficult in the early stages in the two-dimensional model. However, it changes with time. Themelting process is more concentrated in the 3D model but in weaker heat transfer compared to the 2D model.
Different boundary conditions of the heat source have been studied by Kant et al. [290] numerically. Firstly, a constant heat flux between 500 and 500 W/m2 is considered, and secondly, a
sinusoidal function, similar to the previous one, were used for cooling and heating the PCM wall of the cavity. The results showed that the sinusoidal function performs better than the constant function in PCM melting and the melting time is less than the freezing time.
Further types of boundary conditions in the square TES cavity, shown in Fig. 43, has been studied by Satbhai et al. [291]. The simulations performed by solving governing equations using PISO algorithm over unstructured computational cells. This was done using the porous enthalpy model. In the bottom-heated cavity, maximum Nusselt number and little change in total entropy generation were reported compared to the other two models (left- and top-heatedmodels). The top-heatedmodel had the highest melting time compared to the other two models and the bottom-heated model had the highest Nusselt number (3.14). It was 13.47% and 36.14% for left- and upper heated surface, respectively. It was found that themelting time in the upper heatedwall model is about twice (FO ¼ 35.25) compared to other two models. A comparison of the three models in the mean entropy value showed that the bottomheated model has the highest mean entropy value. This value was 16.291 J/m3K. For up- and left-heated walls, a decrease of 0.6% and 0.08% was reported, respectively. The fastest melting with the highest Nu number is associated with the bottom-heated model and this was the best case for energy storage considering the Nusselt, Prandtl, Rayleigh numbers and entropy generation. Natural heat transfer was identified as a dominant heat transfer
mechanism. As displayed, the natural convention at the top of the cavity is greater than that at the bottom of the enclosure. It was also observed that f and m of NEPCM are in a direct relationship, which is one of the negative effects of natural heat transfer. It was also found from diagram I that the PCM full melting time decreases by 29% and 34% by reducing the porosity from 1 to 0.95 and 0.9, respectively. However, from diagram II it can be seen that the complete melting time of the PCM with the porosity of 0.95 is delayed in comparison to the pure PCM, which is originated from the weakness of vortices in the porous PCM.
Zhao et al. [292] carried out a three-dimensional numerical study of PCM melting in a cubic enclosure. An enthalpy-based incompressible Thermal Lattice Boltzmann method (iTLBM) was applied for different heater positions. The results showed that the melting rate is profoundly affected by the heater size and its heat flux strength. Moving the heat flux from the two sides toward the center increases the heat flux rate and thus the melting rate. The change of the location of the heat source from the top to the bottom of the enclosure was found that has an increasing impact on thermal performance.
Their low heat transfer rates lead many efforts to increase the capability of PCM melting processes. Meanwhile, the design of a PCM cavity has also been employed to enhance natural heat transfer. Li et al. [293] explained the two-dimensional PCMmelting process in the walls of a semi-enclosure. They found that vertical adiabatic walls facing the heated wall inversely affected the heat
sidered in Ref. [291].
transfer phenomenon. Thewalls are optimum as themelting flow is in front of them. The effect of other enclosure constraints including the upper and lower walls was also studied. They found that the inclination of the top wall outward generally leads to the acceleration in the heat transfer and heat energy storage during the melting the PCM. But, bottom wall inclination has a little effect. In this study, the Prandtl of 40, Stefan number of 0.33 and Rayleigh number of zero (pure conductivity), 105 and 107 were used. The bottom wall did not affect the upper region due to the buoyancy flow where the melting zone has a large effect. Therefore, it has little effect on PCM melting. Here, it is emphasized that the design of the enclosure should be in a manner that is more in line with natural heat transfer, not vice versa.
Cao et al. [294] investigated the temperature conditions of the enclosure by the deviation of the heat source relative to the center of the horizontal enclosure experimentally and numerically. In this study, the temperature variations in different locations of heat source were measured and numerical model was investigated. By increasing the amount of source deviation from the center, the thermal performance and the melting rate increased. The ideal sample with the best thermal performance (e ¼ 30 mm) was found to have a reduction of 57% in the PCMmelting time. As the Reynolds number increases, natural heat transfer enhances, so the liquid phase front moves faster. The Reynolds number and the ratio of out-of-center heat source have a direct effect on the melting rate.
Vogel and Thess [295] investigated the melting process of octadecane attached symmetrically on both sides in TES systems experimentally and numerically. The aim of this paper was to evaluate the accuracy of the numerical melting model by experimental data. The numerical method that was used to calculate the fluid flow, temperature and phase area included two approaches: the first one uses variable thermophysical properties together with the VOFmethod that is allowed to have air distance over the PCM to consider its expansion. The second one uses Boussinesq approximation and constant thermophysical properties, which are solved in two or three dimensions. Comparison of these two methods showed about 4% downward deviation in the simulation results compared to the experimental results in thermal flow rate, liquid phase fraction and the temperature, i.e. the value of the simulation results was lower than that of experimental ones.
Attaching fins is another approach to increase the heat transfer and rate of phase change in the enclosures. The number and length of fins were studied by Lacroix and Benmadda [296]. It was showed that a few long fins result in a higher melting rate than many short ones. Gharebaghi and Sezai [277] showed that vertical protrusions increase the melting rate. Woon-Shing [297] investigated the melting of paraffin and gallium PCMs in enclosures with different boundary conditions to provide a deep understanding of the phase change and natural convection at large Rayleigh numbers were studied using the porous enthalpy method. The authors proposed relationships for the Nusselt number and the melting volume fraction in terms of the dimensionless governing numbers such as the Fourier and Stefan numbers.
Using FVM and porous enthalpy approach, melting of gallium around a circular cylinder was numerically investigated by Mahdaoui et al. [298]. The results of flow and temperature fields during melting time were presented along with the Nu number. Also, the volume fraction of the liquid and rate of melting were measured with the time in various surface temperature and heat flux. The results of this study highlighted the role of conductive and convection heat transfer in the melting process. Conduction mode was found that plays a central role in heat transfer near the cylinder wall and as the time increases, the convection heat transfer becomes stronger. In addition, the conduction mechanism is dominant under the cylinder.
Using the enthalpy-based LBM, which provides the simplified style of the algebraic velocity distribution function, phase change procedurewas simulated by Jourabian et al. [299] with emphasis on the free convection. Boltzmann’s function, f (x,c,t), denotes the probability of a random particle being positioned at x at time t, moving at the velocity c. This theory may be derived from older theories, including the theory of marker-and-cell and particle tracking. This study was carried out at Stefan number of 10, Rayleigh number of 106, and at different inclination angles relative to the horizon ( 30 to þ30 ). Raising in the Rayleigh number results in a rise in the melting rate for all inclination angles. In addition, when the enclosure rotates counterclockwise, the convection effect is higher and when it rotates clockwise, the effect of thermal conductivity on melting is higher.
Zennouhi et al. [300] investigated the influence of the enclosure angle on melting (Fig. 44). They investigated the melting of gallium at different angles of the enclosure in two-dimensional simulations. They solved the natural convection while phase changing occurs using the FVM and the porous enthalpy technique. Validation of the numerical model was performed by previous numerical results. The results indicated that the melting rate increases by declining the inclination angle from 90 to 0 .
Karami and Kamkari [301] investigated the effect of PCM buoyancy force due to the slope deflection on charge and discharge rates of heat source (Fig. 45). One and three fins in the rectangular enclosure from one side began to heat within the PCM material under 0 to 180 . Luric acid was used as PCM material. Numerical simulations under control volume operationwere also investigated on properties such as phase field, flow field, temperature distribution, heat transfer rate, and TES for different configurations. The results showed that the melting time is declined with the natural convection by increasing the deviation of the rectangular source. The maximum melting time decreases by 72% in the three-fin enclosure and 0 compared to the no-fin enclosure. The results showed that the enclosure with one fin is less time consuming than the onewith three fins. Finally, the inclination angle was found that has a raising effect on Nu number.
Souayfane et al. [302] used the enthalpymethod and studied the phase changes to reveal the favorable impact of natural heat transfer on the thermal performance of PCM melting. In addition, short-wave radiation is also used as a heat source to solve the defined algorithm in the two-dimensional FVM fashion. A numerical platform has been developed for the melting simulation and compared against the available experiments and numerical studies. Then a simplified model was used to melt a type of fatty acid by a combination of natural heat transfer and radiation. This hybrid model was applied by the lattice Boltzmann-discrete ordinate method (LBM-DOM). The simplified suggestedmodel is handy with a higher simulation speed than the CFD and LBM-DOM models. Also, again approved that during the PCM melting process, natural heat transfer acts as a key parameter in raising the average liquid fraction and progressive melting position. Finally, shortwave radiation increases the average liquid fraction.
The effect of inclination angle on melting performance was checked studied by Kamkari and Groulx [303]. The lauric acid melting was investigated at 90 , 45 and 0 in various fins number. Interface movement varies noticeably with the angle and defined the vortex strength such that it was made clear that raising the inclination angle improves either configuration with and without fins. The heat transfer enhancement in the horizontal enclosure and the vertically-finned enclosure with 3 fins was compared with the no-fin vertical enclosure, i.e. this value was 115% and 56%, respectively. This behavior showed that an increase of inclination angle can be used instead of using more fins in the PCM melting process in horizontal enclosures. The horizontal enclosure with
three fins was revealed that has the highest thermal conductivity and thus the lowest melting time.
The instantaneous ice melting within a porous horizontal enclosuremade by nickel steel alloywith two vertical cylinders was studied by Jourabian et al. [304] (Fig. 46). In this paper, the enthalpy-based LBM with dual distribution function on representative elementary volume scale was used. Using porous materials in the base PCM makes the role of conduction dominant and suppressing the vortex strength. The porous model was compared with pure or non-porous PCMmodel. It was found that reducing porosity leads to a decline in the complete melting time and thermal storage capacity of the system. The rate of thermal conductivity was developed in the samples with the highest porosity. It was demonstrated that the pure PCM slowly melted from its top with increasing thermal resistance of the melted layer, leading to a delay in the complete melting of the PCM. By using nickel steel alloy porous matrix in the ice, the conduction heat transfer was dominant and the natural heat transfer flow was stopped. Reducing porosity resulted in a reduction in thermal storage capacity. The
highest porosity samples can be used to achieve the highest heat transfer efficiency in this thermal storage unit. The point to note is that as porosity increases, thermal storage capacity increases but natural heat transfer decreases.
During PCM heat transfer in closed enclosures, natural heat transfer and contact melting act as key factors in heat transfer improvement. An improved Nusselt model for melting PCM melts in rectangular enclosures with different inclination angles was proposed by Zhao et al. [305]. This study was conducted for a 2D experimental model. The melting process of n-octadecane was recorded for square enclosures at different angles (0, 15, 30, 45, 60, 75, and 90) by a digital camera. In this method, the nondimensional height, liquid fraction, and complete melting time were determined. The dimensional height was consistent with the theoretical results and the fastest operation corresponded to 60 - cavity. Natural heat transfer played an essential role in enhancing heat transfer. The fastest melting is for the inclined models than that for horizontal and vertical ones.
A model was developed by Ji et al. [306] to reveal the impact of fin inclination angles of 0 ,þ15 ,þ30 , 15 and 30 . It was found that the angle of 15 is the most suitable configuration for increasing natural heat transfer compared to the other 3 angles. In this model, there was a 23.8% increase in PCM melting time compared to straight fins. However, this time for the models with
the angles of þ15 and þ30 resulted in a reduction of 45.2% and 71.4%, respectively. In other words, the fin with the angle of 15 was found as an optimum value for PCMmelting rate and saving of 62.7% in melting time.
Using longitudinal arrangement of two fins, Ji et al. [307] numerically studied the improvement of a PCM-made TES unit. RT42 was used as PCM in a rectangular enclosure heated at a constant temperature of 70 C to absorb thermal energy. A transient numerical model was developed and the results were validated by natural heat transfer. It was concluded that the short fin embedded on the upper wall and the long fin on the lower wall melts PCM faster. The fin lengths ratio of 0.25 resulted in an enhancement of 25% in the PCM melting time. The optimum arrangement of fins was found for the storage improvement such that, the longer length of the upper fin and the shorter length of the lower one had an unfavorable effect. To study the underlying physics of how the system performance improves by in a special configuration of the fin pairs, the liquid fraction contours showed good behavior of the liquid PCM flow. It was observed that for the length ratio of lower than 1, the free heat transfer flow through the chaotic flow appeared to be quite effective. However, the flow motions guided by natural heat transfer due to the longitudinal ratios more than 1 become weaker. The length ratio of 0.25 showed the highest length of solid-melt interface among other ratios. The average Nusselt number in three stages were compared to show which mechanism is dominant. Further optimization studies showed that when the ratio of length decreases, the full melting time decreases. The solid phase melts by 40.5% faster than the case in which the fins are the same. The time ratio was also decreased by 45% by decreasing the inlet temperature from 70 C to 50 C.
Hong et al. [308] simulated the liquid-solid phase change of the PCM in a square enclosure with isothermal walls. The idea of rotating the enclosure during the melting process was suggested as a feasible way to increase the performance of the energy storage system. The porous enthalpy model was used for this purpose and the numerical model validated with the published papers. The maximum raise in the liquid fraction occurs mostly between 24.3% and 40% standard time units, compared to when the enclosure inversion operation was not performed. The rotated enclosure is the simplest way of increasing the phase change compared to the available methods. In addition, for cases where it is not possible to fully invert, it is recommended to incline the enclosure as far as possible. Good performance by inversion is generally because of the dominancy of the convection mode.
Li et al. [309] compared the natural heat transfer of threemodels of different materials including MPCM slurry, MPCM particle and ordinary PCM (Fig. 47). This test was evaluated by three lower, upper and lateral walls of the enclosure. MPCM slurry exhibited the best thermal control among the three materials. Excluding the effect of natural heat transfer, MPCM slurry had the lowest surface heat when having the highest heat transfer. On the contrary, without fluid convection, the lowest heat transfer and the worst interfacial heat resistance were observed for MPCM particles. The highest increase in temperature gradient was observed for MPCM slurry, especially in the vicinity of the heat source. The highest internal heat distribution was seen from lower heating. MPCM slurry with the lowest MPCM distribution showed the lowest time to reach the melting temperature. The results showed that MPCM slurry exhibits the best thermal control among the two models because of the rise in natural convection. Pure PCM and MPCM particles were placed in second and third place, respectively.
Inaba et al. [310] used a blend of fatty microparticles for their experiments: water, surfactants, and fine particles PCM. The PCM volume concentration ranges from a maximum 30% to the minimum 5% and the experiments were in three separate temperature
phases of the PCM particles within the solid phase, two-phase, and liquid phase. The influence of rectangular enclosure size ratio and PCM concentration on natural heat transfer was examined. They revealed that the Nu value increases partially in the concentration of PCM in the solid phase. The Nusselt number was increased by increasing the concentration of PCM volume at low Ra. No significant difference was observed in PCM free convection in its low concentrations (<10mass%), while it became larger with raising the concentration. Even for low concentrations of PCM, the maximum Nusselt number was reported that has a direct relation with Ra within the phase change region. Scattering of fatty particles had an effect on enhancing natural heat transfer. The modified Stefan number introduced in this study leads to a rise in the dominancy of convection. The Nusselt number in the PCM phase change procedure has an inverse relation with the Stefan number. The Nusselt number increased with the concentration of PCM. It was found that although PCM viscosity may increase with increasing PCM concentration, it has a favorable effect on the thermal performance. The sidewalls effect on natural heat transfer and an increase in temperature on viscosity reduction were evident. Concerning the Nusselt number, it was found that the PCM in the liquid phase and phase change process was more deviated than the solid phase PCM.
Considering the increasing use of PCMs as TES sources, researchers are looking for methods to increase the amount of heat storage in these materials. With the development of human knowledge and the introduction of high-conductive nanomaterials, many researches were done on the phase change of thesematerials, which may be discussed in a few instances.
Using LBM, the melting process of ice inside the bottom-heated enclosure in presence of copper nanoparticles was studied by Feng et al. [311] (Fig. 48b). The results of this study were presented for flow and temperature fields for the three cases of base fluid and nanofluid combinations with volume fractions of 0.5 and 1% and Grashof numbers of 5 104 104 and 2.5 105. The composition of nanoparticles and PCM has higher heat transfer efficiency than pure material. As the concentration of nanoparticles increases, the melting line progresses faster. In addition, the energy stored also increases. On the other hand, it was seen that for high concentrations of nanoparticles for the Grashof number 2.5 105, an asymmetric melting front is created.
Melting of the hybrid of paraffin-alumina nanoparticles in a square enclosure shown in Fig. 48 under cross-sectional heating and cooling was examined by Arici et al. [312]. This study was performed for different volume fractions of 1, 2 and 3%. The highest melting rate was found that happens for the volume fraction of 1% and bottom-heated enclosure. Addition of alumina nanoparticles to paraffin resulted in an increase by 6.7% and 10.6% in the thermal storage and melting rate, respectively, for the concentration of 1%. According to the investigations on nanofluids and the effect of adding nanoparticles to the base fluid, it was observed that the thermal conductivity and viscosity increase and the heat capacity decreases by increasing the volume percentage of nanoparticles [313e316]. Therefore, the results of Arici et al. [312] demonstrated that the buoyancy force cannot overcome the force due to the viscosity by increasing the volume percentage of nanoparticles and enhancing the viscosity. On the other hand, the heat capacity of PCMs is decreased. Hence, the melting rate and thermal energy storage decrease with the volume fraction of nanoparticles.
Similar work on paraffin-copper nanoparticles was conducted by Sebti et al. [317] through the use of enthalpy method. This study showed that the volume fraction of nanoparticles in the base fluid is effective on themelting rate by affecting the rate of conductive heat transfer. This effect results in a raise in the melting rate as the concentration rises. Phase change of water-Cu nanomaterial in an insulated enclosure was examined by Darzy et al. [318] to reveal the
importance of convection effects using LBM (Fig. 48C). In this study, the effect of the heater location inside the enclosure was also investigated. An increase in the concentration from zero to 4% results in a rise in the melting rate by 52.7%, 41.2%, and 30%, respectively, for the location of heat source in top, center, and bottom of the enclosure. Solidification of the same mixture was further analyzed by Kashani et al. [319] with corrugated vertical walls. The effect of wall wave, concentration of nanomaterials, and Grashof number, in wide ranges, on freezing time and natural convection were investigated. In this study, the supercooling phenomenon and the effect of nanoparticle diffusion at the freezing point were ignored. However, it is found that the supercooling occurs in reality because pure water cools to 5 C to 7 C and then begins to freeze. The porosity-enthalpy method was used for numerical study of solidification phenomenon. This method has been used for years as one of the methods of modeling the melting and freezing processes. The energy equation has been derived in terms of enthalpy. The results of this study showed that by increasing the concentration and the Gr value, the Nu value increase. Overall, this study showed that the shape of the enclosure, along with other influencing factors such as nanoparticle volume fraction and free convection rate has a positive impact on the phase change procedure.
Melting of paraffin-aluminum oxide nanofluid was examined by Arasu et al. [323] for the 25 mm 25 mm enclosure. The enclosure was heated from its sidewalls. In this study, the effect of orientation of heat source and volume fraction of aluminum oxide particles on the melting process was investigated. Fig. 49 shows an overview of the enclosure. Navier-Stokes equations and the enthalpy method were solved as the governing equations. The equations were analyzed in FLUENT software. The results showed that the melting
rate rises by 0.02 in the base fluid by increasing the concentration. It was demonstrated that as the concentration increases, the melting rate begins to decrease until the melting rate less than that for pure paraffin for the volume fraction of 5%. The amount of heat absorbed by the nanofluid is declined with the percentage of alumina nanoparticles. Thus, lower volume fractions of alumina nanoparticles in paraffin not only create a better melting process but also increase energy storage capacity for constant dimensions of the enclosure.
Fan and Khodadadi [324] experimentally investigated nonlinear fast freezing in cyclohexane fluid. This compound was prepared using copper oxide nanoparticles of different mass concentrations. The problem was considered one-dimensional for a wall of limited thickness and high depth. Initially, the liquid PCMwas assumed at a temperature above freezing temperature. The sidewall temperature drops suddenly to a temperature lower than the melting point. By neglecting the effects of supercooling, freezing begins rapidly in the adjacent left wall and moves to the right wall. The Fourier equation was used to mathematically describe the conduction and convection in the solid and liquid phases. Khodadadi and Fan [325] described this method in another study to show that the highest freezing rate occurs at volumetric concentration of 0.02, while the freezing rate decreases as the concentration rises by 0.04 probably due to a cross-sectional increase in thermal conductivity of the solid phase. Melting process of nanoparticle-reinforced PCM in the two-dimensional enclosure shown in Fig. 49 was numerically studied by Sebti et al. [326] using FVM over a non-uniform grid. In this study, paraffin-copper nanofluid with different volume fractions was used. The enthalpy-porosity method was used to track the melting line. In this study, the effect of nanoparticle diffusion in the base fluid and some of the governing parameters such as hot
wall temperature and enclosure volume on the flow field, heat transfer rate and melting line motion were investigated. The incompressible steady nanofluid flow was presumed Newtonian with uniform properties, and all thermodynamic properties except the density modeled with Boussinesq approximation were assumed to be constant. The left wall temperature was higher than the melting temperature with a difference of 10 C. They reported the following results: i) at the beginning of the melting, the conduction mechanism plays a key role in thermal performance and the melt line moves parallel to the heated surface, ii) solid fraction decreases linearly with the time, but the freezing rate is initially fast and becomes slow at the end, iii) distribution of nanoparticles within the PCM hasten themelting time due to a rise in the thermal conductivity and Nu, iv) the effect of dispersing nanopowder to the base fluid on heat transfer is greater for larger enclosures, v) the higher the temperature difference, the faster the melting procedure, vi) fluid flow and melting line shape depend on the melt layer thickness and the concentration during phase-change, and vii) the amount of energy stored can be increased by proper nanoparticle dispersion within the PCM.
Hosseinizadeh et al. [327] investigated the melting of a nanoparticle-reinforced material in a cylindrical enclosure experimentally. The base fluid of paraffin and copper nanoparticles were used (Fig. 49). The fluid was precooled with the initial temperature of 23 C. The results of this study showed that adding nanoparticles to the base PCM either increases the thermal conductivity and
declines the latent heat of melting lead to hastening the melting. Khodadadi and Hosseinizadeh [328] simulated the freezing procedure of water using CuO nanoparticles in a rectangular enclosure. Horizontal surfaces were assumed to be insulated and sidewalls were at 283.15 K and 273.15 K. At the freezing point, the temperature on both sides was reduced to 10 K. In this way, the freezing process begins. The simulation was performed using FLUENT software. The results were analyzed for different Grashof and Stefan numbers. In general, using nanoparticles can significantly increase thermal performance.
The annulus filled with nanoparticle-reinforced PCMs was numerically and experimentally studied by Dhaidan et al. [322]. The inner cylinder was kept at a constant heat flux, while the outer surface of the outer cylinder was well insulated. N-octadecane was selected as the PCMwith copper oxide nanoparticles as the thermal conductivity enhancer. The process of melting and changing temperature was observed at many points during the experiment. In this study, the FEM was used for numerical simulations of the process and the effect of volume percentages of nanoparticles and Rayleigh number on melting process was investigated. The results of this study showed that in acute response of melting, the dominant phenomenon of heat transfer is the conduction mechanism, which is characterized by concentric isothermal lines. Subsequently, free convection and the melting rate rises in the upper half of the enclosure. In other words, melting in the lower half is controlled by thermal diffusion and becomes more powerful as the
Ra rises. Altohamy et al. [329] investigated heat transfer in a spherical capsule containing water and alumina nanoparticles experimentally. The results were extracted and compared for distilled water and nanofluid concentrations of 0.5, 1 and 1.5%. A Freon 404 refrigerant with temperatures of 6, 8, 10 and 12 C and different flow rateswas used to cool and freeze the PCM. The results showed that as the volume fraction of nanoparticles increases, the percentage of energy storage increases.
Melting of n-octadecane copper oxide nanomaterial in the horizontal cylinder shown in Fig. 49C under a fixed heat flux on the outer wall was examined experimentally and numerically by Daidan et al. [330]. The experimental apparatus was equipped with several temperature sensors located at different angles of the cylinder. So that it was possible to track the melting line in different test modes. The numerical approach was performed using the FEM. The effect of different volume fractions and Rayleigh numbers on
variables such as heat transfer and melting rates as well as charge time was investigated. They approved that increasing the heat flux and concentration raises the melting rate and declines the charge time. Either the conduction and convection mechanics play important roles in promoting phase change. At the early stages of melting, which most of the cavity is still solid, the conduction phenomenon is dominant. The liquid fraction inside the enclosure increases over time and convection becomes dominant. The interesting point in this study is that the positive effects of nanoparticles occur at low weight fractions. However, at higher weight fractions, the effect of solid nanoparticles was negligible compared to the influence of the viscosity and consequently natural convection heat transfer.
Using the porosity-enthalpy method, Kashani et al. [331] simulated the solidification process of n-hexadecane with copper nanoparticles. The results of this study revealed that the thermal properties inside the base material increase with the addition of
nanoparticles. The researchers believed that using appropriate nanoparticles can improve the properties of the PCM as a storage material.
Zarma et al. [332] investigated photovoltaic focusing on CPVnanoparticles-PCM numerically (Fig. 50). The effect of different nanoparticles of Al2O3, CuO, SiO2 with a mass fraction of 1%e5% on the photovoltaic concentration was investigated. In this research, 2D simulations of models including photovoltaic nanoparticle layers in PCM were validated with experimental data. It was observed that by an increase in the PCM temperature and the melting rate, a reduction in the solar cell temperature and the use of nanoparticles in the PCM lead to that the temperature becomes more uniform and electrical efficiency in the CPV system increases. It was also found that using Al2O3 nanoparticles with a mass fraction of 5% in PCM leads to an electrical efficiency of 8% and a uniform temperature of 12 C, whereas pure PCM results in maximum electrical efficiency of 6.36% and uniform temperature of 20 C. In this study, n-octadecane, paraffin, and graphene were used as PCM.
Melting of three types of CuO nano-PCM including, paraffinwax, coconut oil, and Rubitherm, in a cubic enclosure were compared by Al-Jethelah et al. [333] (Fig. 51). Their melting point respectively were 54 C, 24 C, and 18 Cwith the ambient temperature of 24 C. The left surface was kept at constant temperature and the horizontal and right surfaces were isolated. The continuum and momentum equations were solved for liquid and the energy equation was solved in solid and liquid regions using FEM. The spatiotemporal variation of the melting front was captured as well as the temperature and flow pattern for various nano-PCM
concentrations, Ra and Ste numbers. The rapid propagation of melting front and heat transfer rate were reported as the concentration increased. A scale analysis was first introduced to describe different melting regimes. The results presented were consistent with previous results.
Ren et al. [334] proposed adding nanoparticles and metal foam to the PCM for the purpose of thermal performance improvement. Their study was based on enthalpy and buoyant boundary in the LBM. The average PCM liquid fraction, energy stored per unit width Q, and mean temperature at LHTES were systematically studied in various porosities and sizes of metal foam, nanoparticle volume fraction, and heat pipe radius. The results were as follows: i) the melting rate of PCM with nanoparticles in LHTES can be increased by decreasing the porous metal foam or by increasing the nanoparticle volume fraction. In this paper, an optimum amount of porous metal foam mixture and nanoparticles were obtained to achieve maximum energy storage capacity f¼ 0.01 and εave ¼ 0.95, ii) it was observed that by declining the metal foam porosity at a constant volume, the melting rate of PCM increases. Both the conduction and convection heat transfer was found that have effects in the same order on the thermal performance. For high porous metal foams, the average temperature increases with the porosity size during conduction heat transfer. Reduction of porosity of metal foam can decrease the heat transfer of the LHTES due to the use of metal foam with small porosity size, iii) the heat pipe radius of the LHTES unit has a significant impact. As the diameter increases, the melting rate increases, and iv) the effect of porous metal foam on energy storage in LHTES is greater than that of
xamined by Zarma et al. [332].
nanoparticles. Ebadi et al. [335] studied melting, heat transfer, and TES properties of a CuO nano-PCM in a Cylindrical TES System (C-TES) in various concentrations and Ra values, then they validated the numerical results with experimental ones. The mathematical model based on nonlinear differential equations was used to study mass, momentum, and transport properties within C-TES. The bottom was insulated and it was heated from sides and up surfaces. The numerical results obtained from the solid-melt interface and the liquid fraction for PCM and nano-PCM were compared with the experiments and good agreements were shown. The flow pattern was shown that is not sensitive to the concentration. The results showed that the stored energy did not significantly vary with Ra values in early stages, while its sensitivity becomes more and more over time. Hence, a large difference is observed when the melting increases at high Rayleigh numbers.
Finally, according to recent studies and articles, using latent heat storage units that use PCMs is an effective method to save energy that has received much attention in recent years. PCMs are used to store thermal energy and their importance has environmental and economic aspects. Due to the fact that materials release energy phase change during phase change, their use reduces energy consumption [41,122,336,337].
According to studies, the use of nanoparticles in phase change materials improves the thermal conductivity of phase change materials. In fact, the use of nanoparticles in phase change materials improves the performance of energy storage systems. On the other hand, the use of phase change materials reduces energy consumption and causes temperature uniformity in different temperature fluctuations [41,121,338e341].
Recent studies also demonstrate that when the melting and freezing behavior of PCMs and nano-PCMs are evaluated, their thermophysical properties, especially the viscosity, must also be carefully measured. Previous studies show that the wrong value of viscosity leads to the incorrect output of numerical simulation results from experimental data significantly [342e345].

sections.heading: 12. Conclusions, challenges, and suggestions
sections.text:
In this study, a detailed review of recent researches and developments in PCM technology and their natural convection were presented, focusing on the models used for the numerical
simulations. According to the results of previous studies about the use of PCM for heat energy storage, it can be stated that in all cases the reduction of energy consumption, in some cases up to 20% is one of their advantages (especially during peak power hours). The benefits of using these materials in buildings can be attributed to the increased thermal comfort of residents due to the reduction of temperature fluctuations. Also, the reduction of temperature fluctuations in sensitive cases such as greenhouse, solar heaters, and dryers can affect the desired quality of the finished product. Despite the advantages of using PCMs and their potential for high temperature latent heat storage, there are some technical challenges that need to be addressed in future works, such as supercooling, which is a major problem for PCMs that affects the storage performance and material stability. Therefore, further studies are suggested. The presence of salts and hydrated salts in PCMs causes corrosion and damage to warehouses and building materials, requiring further investigation to determine the compatibility between PCMs and various building materials, which will affect the life and stability of heat storage units. Since PCMmicro-capsulation is a potential solution to the corrosion problem, a standard test method must be established for leakage tests, as most enclosed PCMs are not currently tested. In addition, the micro-encapsulation can be used to increase heat transfer and prevent phase separation during the melting process, so the stability test is crucial for the final evaluation of the effects of the encapsulation process. Although the melting points of most PCMs and nano-PCMs are known, thermal conductivities, densities, specific heat capacities, and volume expansions of liquids and solids are not fully consistent across studies. Therefore, these features are sometimes unavailable for PCMs and nano-PCMs. Thus, to provide reliable results and data, a standard test method and a database should be provided. Increasing heat transfer is another subject that needs further studies, especially with the focus on their thermal conductivities. As one can see from previous researches, one of the potential advances is dispersing highly conductive nanoparticles in PCMs. However, there are a few studies to strengthen PCMs using nanoparticles.
Price of PCMs has been high due to demand and supply. Currently, due to limited demand, they are mainly produced with relatively high prices. However, there is a huge market potential for PCMs in a variety of applications, including building energy management. Since producers set their prices based on future market
expectations, prices decrease in the future. Current studies are expected to evaluate the energy performance of PCMs, thus playing an important role in shaping their vision for building applications. As a result, doing these researches and increasing their use can increase their demand and reduce their prices.
Most researches on change phase problems were performed at temperatures ranging from 0 to 60 C that are proper for heating/ cooling of homes with casual PCMs including, stearic acid, wax, paraffin, Glauber’s salts, and n-octadecane. There are a few studies on thermal heat systems with moderate temperatures for hot side storage that can be used for air conditioners.
Numerical methods are restricted to solve phase change problems in 2D because of the cumbersome equations. For the first time, it was assumed that the phase change problem is controlled by latent heat. However, in recent years, free convection in liquids phase has been taken into account, adding complexities to these problems. Its advantage not to study the melting front makes the enthalpy formulation as one of the common methods to solve phase change problems. Variations in the obtained models to determine the melting and strength effects of PCMs, which is characterized by different methods of analyzing and selecting, is observable. Therefore, the selection of correlations for design purposes and quantitative comparison is required. Neither international nor national standards for PCM tests were documented to date. Thus, researchers have used different methods for testing and analysis for many years. Different values of PCMs thermophysical properties were used showing a major problem of testing standards.
Author statement
Sara Rostami: Writing, Review & Editing. Masoud Afrand: Formal analysis, Review & Editing. Amin Shahsavar: Methodology, Conceptualization. M. Sheikholeslami: Investigation, Review & Editing. Rasool Kalbasi: Investigation, Review & Editing. Saeed Aghakhani: Methodology, Conceptualization. Mostafa Safdari Shadloo: Review & Editing. Hakan F. Oztop: Review & Editing

metadata.abstractText: Phase change materials (PCMs) are capable of storing energy as latent energy by changing the phase and provide the stored energy when they are returned to their initial phase at a desired time. Due to the varying melting temperature of these materials, their application in air conditions of buildings, as well as the provision of hygienic hot water has received much attention, recently. This paper first provides a detailed illustration of phase change materials and their working principle, different types, and properties. Then a characteristic example of PCMs in solar energy storage and the design of PCMs are reviewed and analyzed. Next, this paper focuses on the heat transfer, melting and freezing processes of PCM/nano-PCMS including different models and experimental research on the natural convection and thermal energy storage. Finally, some challenges and suggestions are presented following the conclusion of this article. It is found that these materials generally improve system efficiency. Without using mechanical equipment, these materials are naturally adapted to the temperature fluctuations of the environment, leading to a reduction in energy consumption and subsequently energy management. © 2020 Elsevier Ltd.
